title: Dennard could see some action on defense Sunday
text:
Dennard could see some action on defense Sunday 
Updated: Thu, Oct 01 2015, 06:27 PM 
CINCINNNATI (Richard Skinner) -- With safety George Iloka possibly missing Sunday's game against the Kansas City Chiefs due to an ankle injury and starting corners Adam Jones and Dre Kirkpatrick each a bit nicked up as well it might finally open the door for 2014 first-round draft pick Darqueze Dennard to get some significant playing time on defense. 
It hasn't been Dennard's lack of ability that has kept from playing much other than special teams, but players like Jones and Kirkpatrick and veteran Leon Hall playing so well in front of him. 
"His time will come," said Bengals head coach Marvin Lewis. "We need all these guys. His production in other areas is great; we have to keep it up. He’s had a good couple weeks of practice since coming back from (a groin) injury he suffered in training camp, and that’s what you have to do ... go and be ready. That’s the hardest part of the NFL, staying ready and working on your craft all the time. And when your number (is) called, being ready to go and respond." 
Dennard admitted it was hard last season playing almost exclusively on special teams, but he said he took a new mindset into the offseason and heading into this season. 
"I think this year I'm handling it a little bit better and being more positive," said Dennard, who started 38 games in his college career at Michigan State. "I just think about as Aaron Rodgers/Brett Favre. Aaron sat three years behind a Hall of Fame player. I just have to be positive and stay ready like A-Rodg did and you see what kind of player he turned out to be, and that's just what I've got to do." 
Dennard finished second on the team in special teams tackles last season and is tied for first this season. 
He did get 22 defensive snaps in the season-opening blowout win at Oakland, but got just one the next game against San Diego and none in this past Sunday's win at Baltimore. That doesn't mean Lewis doesn't have confidence in Dennard. 
"He’ll play just as well as what we’re playing and I feel good about that," said Lewis. "He's smart, and he's trained to play a bunch of different spots there, which is good." 
That means if Iloka doesn't play and Hall moves from being the nickel corner covering the slot receiver to safety on passing downs then Dennard could see action either covering the slot receiver or moving outside with Jones moving to cover the slot receiver. 
Whatever situation he's placed, Dennard said he'll be ready to play. 
"You have to take pride in what you do and you can't not be ready and get thrown into the game and mess up and look bad," said Dennard. "You have to stay ready. Football is a dangerous sport. You never know when somebody goes down - it's a long season. I just have to prepare like I'm a starter and that's what I've been doing."
